terms.definition: Software as a Service - a cloud-based software delivery model where applications are hosted by a service provider and accessed via the internet
A centralized repository of information, documentation, and resources that provides answers to common questions and solutions to problems
A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or code over time, allowing users to see revision history and revert to previous versions
A chronological record of system activities and document changes that provides evidence of compliance and accountability for regulatory inspections
A security method that restricts system access and document editing permissions based on a user's role within an organization
Enterprise Resource Planning - integrated software systems that manage and automate core business processes across an organization
Internet of Things - a network of physical devices embedded with sensors and software that can collect and exchange data over the internet
The ability for multiple users to simultaneously edit, comment on, and work together on documents with instant updates visible to all participants
Pre-configured sequences of tasks and approvals that execute automatically based on triggers, reducing manual effort in document management processes
A unified system where all documents and records are stored in a single, accessible location rather than scattered across multiple platforms
Ready-made document formats and structures that can be customized and reused to standardize documentation processes and ensure consistency
A centralized location where all critical information is stored and maintained, ensuring everyone accesses the same accurate and up-to-date data
The process of combining data from different sources and systems into a unified view, enabling seamless information flow between applications
The systematic monitoring and documentation of adherence to regulatory requirements and industry standards throughout a project lifecycle
The automatic updating and alignment of documents across multiple systems to ensure all versions remain consistent and current
